div.head: Introduction
div.p: This document compiles various concrete use cases implementing the suggested standOff element in order to refine the possible constraints that may bear upon it and its sub-elements. It is based on the experience gained in various projects since the initial workshop that took place in ... and that launched the definition of this element as well as on some ongoing activities that are being pursued in several national projects in France and Germany (among others), in international institutions (EPO) as well as in the content of several ISO projects (some of which have already been published as standards).
The major conclusions that can be drawn from these use cases are the following:

div.head: Overview of the standOff proposal
div.note: This section should be conceived as text that would go in the guidelines
div.p: This proposal implements embedded stand-off annotations, i.e. annotations to an existing document that have the following properties:

list.item: Annotations do not alter any part of the document itself, header nor content
There may be as many complementary and competing annotations attached to a given document as wanted
Annotations occur at a precidsely determined place in the TEI docuement organisation, namely as an addtional resource, child of TEI or teiCorpus We need a scenario for such a usage
Annotations are conveyed with their specific meta-data

div.head: The standOff element
div.p: The standOff element is the container of any group of coherent annotations attached to a TEI docuemnt. Its main charcateristics are:

list.item: It is attached to the top level of a TEI document by being a membe rof model.resourceLike
Its content model resembles that of a TEI document by comprising a header (teiHeader), additional resources (model.resourceLike) and a content (one or several listAnnotation elements)

div.head: The listAnnotation element
div.p: The listAnnotation element is a general container allowing one to structure annotaiton in various subsection. In this respect, its role is analogous to the one played by div in a general TEI document. Still, div could not be taken up here in order to be able to keep to a very restrained content model.
As an iterative and recursive element, listAnnotation can be typed to indicate the organisational logic of the annotations.

div.head: Aligning with the Open Annotation model
Quick presentation of the Open Annotation model
div.p: The Open Annotation data model articulates around three complementary components:

list.item: Target: that identifies one or several resources about which something is said
Body: that contains what is said about the resource
Annotation: that links one or several targets with 0-n bodies

div.head: Named entity recognition within the OA model
Introduction
div.p: Named entity recognition is a typical use case for stand-off annotation. It is usually based upon an automatic analysis process of a digital text which produces various hypotheses as to which entities (persons, events, organisations, dates, etc.) are actually mentionned. Given the variety of possible hypotheses, and the quantity of information that a NER module may produce, it does not make sense in putting the resulting annotation inline. Besides, there is a need to record some specific metadata related to the NER process such as the tool that has been used, the parameters given to the tool, etc.

The idea here is to contribute to the definition of a standardised output interface for NER components or online services so that such annotations can actually be re-used, compared, visualised in a systematic way.

div.head: Morphosyntactic annotation
div.p: ISO 24611 (MAF) contains a TEI based serialisation for morpho-syntactic annotations. The underlying model of ISO 24611 is based upon a two level model distinguishing between:

list.item: Tokens: elementary units segmented in the source textual content, and
Word forms: the abstract lexical units that may group together one or several tokens.

div.note: A token can also be associated to more than one word forms, e.g. in French: du, combining de and le.

div.head: Reference annotation
div.p: Reference annotation consists in identifying referring expression in text or discourse and qualify the relation between them (e.g. anaphorical links) or with existing or putative external entities (e.g. in the case of deixis).
